data.title: Spring 1960
data.text:
CHRONOLOGY

ALFRED STIEGLITZ: Born January 1, 1864, Hoboken, New Jersey. 1867: First foreshadowing of preoccupation with the visual: Intense interest, at age of three, in carrying about with him, in his belt, portrait of "beautiful little boy cousin”. 1871: Edward and Hedwig Stieglitz (Alfred’s parents), decided to move their family to New York City. Alfred was the eldest of six children. 1871-77: He attended Charlier Institute, N.Y.C. 1872: First "more or less conscious” interest in photography. Began to accompany photographers into darkrooms whenever he was photographed as a child. Took his toy race-horses, quite on his own, to be photographed by professional photographer. 1876: First visit to Lake George. 1877-81: Attended N. Y. Public School, 1877-79; College of City of N. Y., 1879-81. 1881: Edward Stieglitz retired from business, taking entire family to Europe, so that his children might receive best possible education. 1881-90: Alfred attended Realgymnasium, Karlsruhe, Germany ( 1881-82 ) ; Charlottenburg (Berlin) Polytechnic (1882-90). First studied mechanical engineering, but decided to concentrate instead upon photography. First photographs made in Berlin, 1883. Traveled and photographed extensively throughout Europe in ’80’s, making constant experiments. 1885-86: Began to write occasionally for photographic and other magazines. 1886: Sent dozen prints to London A?nateur Photographer Competition, receiving Honorable Mention. Rest of family returned to U. S. Edward first rented, then, in 1887, bought Oaklawn, Lake George, where Alfred henceforth was to spend many summers, and to make some of his most important photographs. 1887: Won first prize in London Amateur Photographer Holiday Work Competition, his first official recognition in photographic world. 1888: Returned to America for summer, going back to Europe same year to continue with studies in Berlin. 1889: Began to exhibit his photographs, and to write about photography more extensively. 1890: Returned to U. S., from then on residing in N. Y. C. 1890-95: Entered photo-engraving business. Began to wage fight for what came to be known as modern "American Photography”; to "do battle” for recognition of photography on same basis as other art forms; to arrange numerous exhibits of advance-guard photography. Continued to write for various photographic and other magazines. His photographs began to be published more widely. Exhibition authorities throughout world (mainly art-exhibition authorities interested in photography) increasingly called upon him to select and send whatever American photographic work he felt to be of significance to important photographic exhibits both in U. S. and abroad. Within short period won over 150 medals for own photographs. 1891: Joined N. Y. Society of Amateur Photographers. 1893: Became editor of American Amateur Photographer. Married Emmeline Obermeyer. (Daughter, Katherine, born 1898). During '90’s made constant photographic experiments. Was one of first to make night pictures of artistic significance; also photographs of moving objects in snow, rain, mist, fog. Continued to advance art and science of photography in numerous ways. Made several summer trips to Europe up to 1911. Also spent several summers in Long Branch, West End, and other resorts near New York. Occasional summers at Lake George during this period. Was first American to be elected to London Linked Ring (advanceguard English Photographic Society). 1895: Withdrew from business. 1896: Resigned from editorship of American Amateur Photographer. When Society of Amateur Photographers amalgamated with N. Y. Camera Club, accepted Vice-Presidency of latter. 1897-1902: Edited Camera Notes, official organ of N. Y. Camera Club. 1902: Founded both publication Camera Work and Photo-Secession movement. Began to organize exhibits of work by members of Photo-Secession. 1905: With cooperation of Edward Steichen, opened Photo-Secession Gallery, 291 Fifth Avenue, N.Y.C., which, in time, came to be known simply as 291 ■ Continued to exhibit, publish, fight for, and buy work of most creative photographers of the period; also to publish material relating to the arts other than photography. Among photographic work championed by Stieglitz: that of David Octavius Hill, Julia Cameron, Gertrude Käsebier, Edward Steichen, Clarence White, Alvin Langdon Coburn, Craig Annan, Robert Demachy, Puyo, Renée Le Bègue, Hans Watzek, Heinrich Kühn, Hugo Henneberg, Baron De Meyer ; later Paul Strand, and, still later, Ansei Adams and Eliot Porter. Stieglitz became honorary member of Royal Photographic Society of London. Beginning in 1908 publicly introduced Modern Art in U. S. for first time, at Photo-Secession Gallery, in addition to continuing to hold exhibitions of work of most advanced photographers, including his own. Held first exhibits in U. S. of Rodin drawings, and work by Matisse, 1908; Alfred Maurer, John Marin, Marsden Hartley, ToulouseLautrec (lithographs), Marius de Zayas, 1909; Arthur Dove, Henri Rousseau, Cézanne, Gordon Craig, 1910. Held first comprehensive exhibit Max Weber, Picasso Complete Evolution through Cubism, 1911; work by untaught children, Manolo, 1912; Francis Picabia 1913; Brancusi, African Sculpture, Braque, 1914; Eli Nadelman 1915; Georgia O’Keeffe 1916; Gino Severini, S. Macdonald Wright, 1917, etc. 1910: Largely as result of his tireless efforts, Albright Gallery (Buffalo) was first museum in U. S. to buy photographs on same basis as other art, at time of important Albright International Exhibition of Pictorial Photography. 1915-16: Magazine 291, published under Stieglitz’s auspices, influenced development of Dadaism. 1917: Gallery at 291 Fifth Avenue closed. Last number of Camera Work published.

From this period to time of his death, spent virtually every summer at Lake George. 1917-25: After 291, arranged various exhibits of American artists he had been championing at Montross, Daniel and Anderson Galleries. Held three important shows of his own work at latter galleries: 1921, 1923, 1924. Publication Manuscripts issued, 1922-23. 1924: Married Georgia O’Keeffe. Received Royal Photographic Society Award, "Progress Medal’’, for publication of Camera Work. Boston Museum of Fine Arts acquired Stieglitz prints (Metropolitan Museum did so in 1928). 1925-29: Intimate Gallery: Showed primarily American artists, mainly work of Marin, O’Keeffe, Demuth, Dove, Hartley, Strand, "plus x”. 1929-46: An American Place exhibits were devoted primarily to work in media other than photography, but photographs were also shown, including Stieglitz’s own work. Continued holding annual exhibits of Marin, O’Keeffe, Dove. Published Letters of John Marin (Edited, with Introduction by Herbert J. Seligmann) ; Dualities by Dorothy Norman. 1933: Metropolitan Museum acquired important Stieglitz collection of photographs by others. 1934: America and Alfred Stieglitz, a Collective Portrait (Doubleday, Doran; Literary Guild Selection). 1935: Stieglitz photographs presented anonymously to Cleveland Museum, and exhibited there. 1940: Awarded Honorary Fellowship by Photographic Society of America. 1944: Exhibit of selections from Stieglitz’s collection of paintings and photographs: History of an American, Alfred Stieglitz: "291” and after, Philadelphia Museum of Art. 1946: Stieglitz died, July 13th. Since his death: 1947: Museum of Modern Art, N. Y. C. exhibits of selections from Stieglitz’s photographs and Collection. (The Museum’s first acquisition of Stieglitz prints, 1941). Stieglitz Memorial Portfolio (Twice A Year Press). 1949: Stieglitz’s collection of paintings and photographs divided among Metropolitan Museum of Art, Art Institute of Chicago, National Gallery of Art, Philadelphia Museum of Art, Fisk University, Library of Congress. Later, further Stieglitz photographs were acquired by George Eastman House, Rochester, N. Y., San Francisco Museum, etc. Stieglitz archives established at Yale University, New Haven. "Alfred Stieglitz Collection of Modern Art for Fisk University” exhibition at Fisk University. 1950: "100 U. S. Painters of 20th Century” exhibit, Metropolitan Museum of Art, N. Y. C. (Some of paintings from Stieglitz’s Collection given to Metropolitan Museum were shown in this exhibit). 1951 : Exhibition dedicated to Stieglitz held at Taft Museum, Cincinnati. Exhibition: "Selections from the Alfred Stieglitz Collection, on extended loan from the Metropolitan Museum of Art” held at Museum of Modern Art, N. Y. C. 1955: Exhibit of Stieglitz portraits of Dorothy Norman, together with Norman portraits of Stieglitz, Limelight Gallery, N. Y. C. 1957: Exhibition Stieglitz photographs from George Eastman House Collection, Dryden Gallery, Rochester, N. Y. 1958: Exhibition Stieglitz photographs, National Gallery of Art, Smithsonian Institute, Washington, D. C. Exhibition: "Stieglitz Circle”, Pomona College Galleries, Claremont, California. (Stieglitz has been widely written about both during his lifetime and since his death. His photographs have been extensively exhibited and reproduced).
